subject: T'Other Shoe Drops...
event:
... onto THE DAILY BEAST.

A couple of weeks ago, I gave THE DAILY BEAST a list of my Top Ten SF Films of All Time.

This morning we have the companion piece: my Top Ten Fantasy Films of All Time.

http://www.thedailybeast.com/blogs-and-stories/2011-04-11/george-rr-martin-game-of-thrones-writers-top-10-fantasy-films/

You can stop holding your breath now.

props.current_music: Did You Ever Have to Make Up Your Mind?

comments.article: ever seen bakshi's wizards? that and dragonslayer are by far my favorites.
Last night on Chuck, Chuck was reading a book and said out loud something to the effect of "No Eddard, don't let your kids have dire wolves.  That sounds like a bad idea."
comments.subject: Mention on Chuck last night
Re: Mention on Chuck last night
Re: Mention on Chuck last night

comments.article: No Hawk the Slayer, George? Swords at dawn it is! :D

Lord of the Rings really is an almost-perfect adaptation of Tolkien's master work. The Scouring was so central to Tolkien's overall tone, but I understand that as a film it may have seemed as something of a downer (and an anticlimactic end for Saruman).

Love that you have Princess Bride on there as well. It's one of those movies, next to Willy Wonka (the original film version), that just gets better as I get older and the jokes make more and more sense.

I wonder if you saw the film adaptation of Stardust. It loses some of the magic in the transition, including the achingly beautiful ending, but I thought it was a good example of how to adapt and change a story from page to screen.

It's been a long time since Lord of the Rings put fantasy front and center, and while some good stuff, like Pan's Labyrinth, has been released since then, it seems that Twilight and its ilk have overtaken the supernatural. I can't wait for Game of Thrones and The Hobbit to rectify the situation.
comments.subject: Loved the list

comments.article:
This is an unrelated comment. I was unsure where to post this, so I picked your most recent thread.

In last nights episode of NBC's Chuck the title character is reading a book and states out loud something to the effect of "Eddard, letting your children keep direwolves is a bad idea."

Thought you'd find it cool that there was a nod to your work in the show.
For those in the U.S., the episode is now available on Hulu.com. The reference is around the 1:50 mark. It's goofy (and fun!)
no love for The 13th Warrior?
Good call -- I love "13th Warrior."  Very underrated movie.

I knew LotR had to be there (and is deservedly #1), but how thrilled am I that The Princess Bride is not only there but #2? (All my notebook computers have been named Inigo Montoya and wear a "Hello, My Name Is" sticker, my iPod is Princess Buttercup, and my netbook is Dread Pirate. Not that I have a theme going or anything.)
I am, at the moment that I write this, wearing the shirt with that nametag on it.  Thought you ought to know.
comments.subject: Hello my name is...
Re: Although I love the movie ...

comments.article:
Good list, George, although...

Where's Conan the Barbarian? If the horrid, soul-destroying of Ladyhawke can't make you leave that film off the list, surely the iconic Basil Poledouris score could elevate Conan at least to an honorable mention! The atmosphere and mood of the film doesn't hurt, either, nor does James Earl Jones' performance or Arnie's... well, presence anyways, if not performance.

Linda shares your issues with Nigel Terry, re: Excalibur. I think once he grows the beard, he comes across rather a lot better. Without it, I just keep thinking of snivelling, miserable Prince John in The Lion in Winter.
I sincerely agree with you, Ran. List needs some Conan love.

I know you said in the fantasy column that you were omitting animated movies, but this applies to the sci-fi list as well.  I find these lists are lacking anime titles...be it Akira for sci-fi or spirited away for fantasy.
comments.subject: Anime

comments.article:
Sorry George, I have to disagree with your #1(23). While I think "Fellowship" has its flaws, it is probably as good an adaptation of the book as is possible, and it might deserve a spot in the top 10 if just for that reason. But with "The Two Towers" Jackson went from simplifying so he could adapt a complex story into a movie to adding new scenes and ideas to the story. It was not an improvement, and "Return" was more of the same. But even as flawed adaptations of a beloved story, the second two were flawed movies, in as much as I found myself checking my watch while watching both of them in the theater.

Perhaps surprisingly, given that, you and I are pretty much in agreement for the rest of your list. I haven't seen "Dark City", so I can't say there. And while The Labyrinth of the Fawn is a great movie, I am not sure I would include it here, since I think (as you speculate) that it isn't really a fantasy as much as it is a story about fantasy as escape. I would probably include "Conan the Barbarian" somewhere lower on the list (Arnold isn't a great choice for Conan as he was written, but the rest of the cast was strong and the soundtrack was as strong as "Ladyhawke"s was weak. The story, while a mish-mash of various Conan stories, satisfies) and slide "Time Bandits" in somewhere high on the list.

Like you, find "Excalibur" a strange beast. I hated it when it came out, then learned to accept (or ignore) its flaws and delight in the dialogue and acting; when they work, they work very, very well. "Legend" falls into the 'guilty pleasures' range; it has its moments, but also its very curious flaws. When my son asked to see it, we started out watching the Director's Cut, and while it doesn't explain those flaws, the fact that the released movie was so different from what was originally envisioned does explain some of the movie's oddities.

Finally, "La Belle et La Bete" was one of the first movies I bought when I finally got a DVD player. Most modern fantasy fans haven't seen it, so it wouldn't be on most folks top-ten lists, but it would be if they saw it.

Now I need to go back and look at the SF list...

Agree with you on LotR. Personally, I would call Excalibur the #1 fantasy movie ever made. Parts of it are a bit of a mess, but so many scenes are utterly perfect. Nicol Williamson = best Merlin ever. Excalibur also featured the best music in a fantasy film by a long shot.

I could not agree with you more about the treatment of King Arthur in film. Excalibur had some good moments, but was mostly laughable. "Woah, like lightning!" http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KjsiGd8iAfs Very sad.
The new King Arthur was terrible as well - for so many reasons I can't begin to name them - let's just say it was a different story altogether!
I would love to see a Modern Classic treatment of the legend - if that makes any sense at all! I want the romance, the battles, the betrayal, the knights, Morgan and Morgause, Merlin! And the sword! The real Guinevere! Gawain! Gareth! All of it!
It is one of the most beautiful and compelling stories ever told - I don't understand why it hasn't been done properly.
What does it take to write a script? Seriously, someone has to do it!
comments.subject: Re: King Arthur

comments.article: Oh also - have you read Bernard Cornwell's Arthur trilogy? I have always wanted it made into movies. That would be amazing!
comments.subject: Re: King Arthur

comments.article:
Aww, man, you had me up until that last mention of "Willow" and how it set fantasy films back 20 years. As a kid, I LOVED "Willow" (and I think it still holds up as a fun movie, wonderful score, etc.). It - along with Ahhnold's "Conan the Barbarian," D&D, and the ElfQuest comics - got me into the fantasy genre...

Anyway, aside from that, I really enjoyed your picks. I'm glad you have "Dragonslayer" on there. Very underrated movie. And I love that you mention how great the dragons looked in "Reign of Fire," another very underrated movie, in my opinion.

And, of course, the "Lord of the Rings" films. I'm beyond happy that those are your #1 picks, because they're mine too. :)
Funny that no one's mentioned Willow yet. I'd say it at least matches half of the list. :)

Thank you!!! I CANNOT believe that Willow was not on that list...

Mr. Martin... did you forget? Were you busy whilst writing that list?

No Conan? No Willow? No Munchausen? My goodness.. Im surprised.
I can't believe that the movie industry is remaking Conan. WTF? As if the first one wasn't bad enough.

Have you actually seen the first "Conan the Barbarian" movie?  It's an amazing movie. I think too many people write it off as just being a dumb Arnold flick (and the sequel, "Conan the Destroyer," doesn't help that image). But it's surprisingly good and non-cheesy... It would be in my top 5 fantasy movies.

Princess Bride, we actually opened up our wedding with: Marriage, Marriage is what brings us together today! We couldn't get him to say it 'properly' though ;-)

Great list George! I love people who are posting and saying why no Never Ending Story or why no HP...heck, I was gonna ask why no HP, but then I realized, it's your list! If I want to have my own, then I need to make an awesome story and have millions of fans, then I can make my list! Is Batman:The Dark Night fantasy?
comments.subject: Great List

comments.article: *Knight, ugh, should proof ;-)...
comments.subject: Re: Great List

comments.upictitle: Stop drooling at my pic!!!!: Author pose
comments.article:
Nice to see Dark city getting appreciation. I, too, only saw it when it was on video, and quite a few years after release. I often think it is like the Matrix but better.

And +1 for Dragonslayer too.

Flight of Dragons would also be a favourite of mine, good voice cast. Also The Fifth Element is up there too, which I think is fantasy enough although being classed as Science Fiction.

comments.upictitle: Peppy: Cuteness Personified! (by triplem and aq
comments.article: I clicked expecting a bunch of obscure films I've never seen or heard from before, and was pleasantly surprised by the list's accessibility. Fun read!

uh, i had to swallow at those conclusion-lines on LOTR. "If you don't like these films, you don't like fantasy."

I for one don't like the films. Not because they are a bad adaption, but mainly because I can't stand the epicness, the sweetness, the humour, and above all, the epic music. At every occassion there is some heroic music fanfaring and foretelling that in the next moment the heroes are gonna succeed. It really destroys the good parts for me.

Other than that its candy for the eyes and most of it exactly like I imagined before.

Dark City! Yes! I caught that one totally on a whim in a tiny theatre back in 1998 because I didn't feel like going home yet. One of the best spur-of-the-moment decisions I ever made. I was mesmerised with the gothicness of it. :-)
Great picks but you forgot the best fantasy movie ever made.  Conan the Barbarian.  Where's the love?  Best fantasy film ever!
Thanks for putting Ladyhawke on there.  Always been one of my very favorites and criminally underrated.

George, I love this list. It's almost exactly the list I would have chosen, except that I would have also selected Conan the Barbarian, which is full of cheese, but it's some seriously awesome cheese.

It almost goes without saying that the dreadful sequel, Conan the Destroyer, deserves a kingly spot on any Worst Fantasy Films list.

I have to say that I agree with your list! (I might change the order, but that's not important)
I also liked your honorable mentions.
I have a soft spot for Thief of Bagdad and I love all of the old Ray Harryhausen.

A great list. My wife got the serious giggles during our wedding rehearsal, and when I asked her (perhaps a little unhappily) what she had found so funny about pledging to stay with me for the rest of her life, she said, "Mawwiage. Is what bwings us togethew. Today."

Then *I* couldn't stop laughing. The preacher was underwhelmed.

Glad to see you made the correct choice for #1. :)

I would have put Conan the Barbarian in there somewhere, though.
comments.subject: Good list

comments.article:
A few of my own, not mentioned:

Scrooge (1970)
Time Bandits (1981)
Army of Darkness (1992)
Conan the Barbarian (1982)
Don Juan DeMarco (1995)
Groundhog Day (1993)

And The Adventures of Baron Munchausen (1988) is a movie that defines what fantasy is for me:
"Reality? Your 'reality', sir, is lies and balderdash, and I'm delighted to say that I have no grasp of it whatsoever."
